Miller)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f4c0d517ffa48002894d125?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn37@2020_4/2020/08/31/06-00-58-277_608961a00e5e39c3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?i=2m0PAvPN6dM:Yn0qFDVsHIQ:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn47@2020_2/2020/08/31/06-00-59-109_05d2c3f5f68faf34.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn81@2020_2/2020/08/31/06-00-57-877_99a57cc2511f53cd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=bcOpcFrp8Mo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn53@2020_2/2020/08/31/06-00-56-954_403f715e664a4d00.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?i=2m0PAvPN6dM:Yn0qFDVsHIQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn14@2020_5/2020/08/31/06-01-14-706_07047fdc223e2a96.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=cGdyc7Q-1BI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn70@2020_3/2020/08/31/06-01-02-412_be4dce30169e75ab.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=QXVau8BzmBE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn2@2020_6/2020/08/31/06-01-03-283_c4d57f9dd1ff11a2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn46@2020_1/2020/08/31/06-01-03-681_0165ab2292566722.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=7Q72WNTAKBA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn18@2020_6/2020/08/31/06-00-58-166_b28aa1f69f1eb446.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider/~4/2m0PAvPN6dM":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn68@2020_2/2020/08/31/06-01-03-626_a46a0184e60f2b90.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598853650319},{"createdTime":"2020-08-31 14:00:50","updatedTime":"2020-08-31 14:00:50","title":"Warren Buffett turns 90 today. Here are 5 of the legendary investor's best birthday stories.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/warren-buffett-90th-birthday-stories-sees-candies-geico-berkshire-hathaway-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f49246ccd2fec00296a4c9b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"warren buffett\" height=\"1641\" width=\"3283\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Berkshire Hathaway CEO Warren Buffett talks to reporters while holding an ice cream at a trade show during the company&#39;s annual meeting in Omaha, Nebraska May 3, 2014.\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Rick Wilking</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong>Warren Buffett's 90th birthday is on Sunday.</strong></li><li><strong>The billionaire investor and Berkshire Hathaway CEO has a lot to celebrate, including his lucrative Apple bet, charity work, and remarkable career.</strong></li><li><strong>Here are five of Buffett's best comments and stories about birthdays, which involve Berkshire-owned See's Candies, Geico, and Nebraska Furniture Mart as well as two birthday parties.</strong></li><li><strong><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</strong></strong><hr ></li></ul><p>Warren Buffett turns 90 on Sunday, August 30.</p><p>The legendary investor and Berkshire Hathaway boss, already the oldest and longest-serving CEO of a S&#38;P 500 company, has plenty to celebrate:</p><ul><li>The so-called \"Oracle of Omaha\" took Berkshire's reins in 1965 and has grown it into a $500 billion conglomerate that owns scores of businesses including See's Candies, Geico, Dairy Queen, Duracell, NetJets, PacifiCorp, Precision Castparts, and the BNSF railroad.</li><li>Berkshire's stock portfolio includes a 5.7% stake in Apple worth $123 billion <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-123-billion-apple-stake-worth-starbucks-boeing-ibm-2020-8-1029531998\">at the last count</a>, a 12% stake in Bank of America <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-bank-of-america-buying-years-pay-off-experts-2020-8-1029477087#\">valued at $27 billion</a>, and billion-dollar positions in Coca-Cola, Kraft Heinz, JPMorgan, and other blue-chip companies.</li><li>The Berkshire chief has inspired countless investors and managers including <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/google-founders-modeled-alphabet-warren-buffett-berkshire-hathaway-2019-12-1028737463\">Google founders</a> Sergey Brin and Larry Page, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-airbnb-brian-chesky-get-rich-slow-ipo-filing-2020-8-1029520058#\">Airbnb CEO</a> Brian Chesky, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/softbank-masa-son-warren-buffett-rabbit-duck-illusion-rebrand-investor-2020-2-1028899468\">SoftBank CEO</a> Masayoshi Son, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/billionaire-investor-chamath-palihapitiya-models-firm-warren-buffett-berkshire-hathaway-2020-6-1029349522\">Virgin Galactic chairman</a> Chamath Palihapitiya, and <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/bill-ackman-put-200-million-warren-buffett-berkshire-hathaway-coronavirus-2020-4-1029071562?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\">Pershing Square CEO</a> Bill Ackman.</li><li>Buffett has taken part in dozens of high-profile deals such as <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-berkshire-hathaway-goldman-sachs-sale-billions-return-bailout-2020-5-1029212109\">bailing out Goldman Sachs</a>, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-invested-3-billion-general-electric-ge-2008-crisis-2020-6-1029327040#\">General Electric</a>, and <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-loaned-300-million-harley-davidson-2009-financial-crisis-2020-6-1029306090#\">Harley-Davidson</a> during the financial crisis, and <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-spent-billions-help-mars-buy-wrigley-2008-crisis-2020-7-1029366581#\">helping to finance</a> Mars' takeover of Wrigley around the same time.</li><li>He has <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-gives-3-billion-charity-37-billion-overall-2020-7-1029376085?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest#est#\">gifted $37 billion</a> to philanthropic organizations in the past 14 years. Through the <a href=\"https://givingpledge.org/\">Giving Pledge</a>, which he launched with Bill and Melinda Gates in 2010, he has also secured commitments from dozens of the world's wealthiest people to give at least half their fortunes to good causes.</li><li>Buffett continues to move markets and spark conversations. Berkshire's dumping of its airline holdings in April <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-trump-calls-out-airline-stock-sales-made-mistake-2020-6-1029285301#\">drew criticism</a> from President Donald Trump, while slashing its bank holdings and making its first investment in a gold miner last quarter <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-berkshire-hathaway-barrick-gold-miner-investment-big-change-2020-8-1029508701#\">raised a lot of eyebrows</a> in the investment community.</li></ul><p>In recognition of Buffett turning 90, here are five of his best comments and stories about birthdays:</p><h2>1. Aiming for 100</h2><p>Geico, one of Buffett's oldest and most lucrative investments, has surpassed rivals such as Progressive and Allstate in terms of premium volumes over the years. Buffett wants the auto insurer to be number one in 10 years' time.</p><p>\"On August 30, 2030 &#8212; my 100th birthday &#8212; I plan to announce that Geico has taken over the top spot, \" Buffett said in his <a href=\"https://www.berkshirehathaway.com/letters/2015ltr.pdf\">2015 shareholder letter</a>. \"Mark your calendar.\"</p><p>Buffett reiterated his goal at Berkshire's 2016 annual meeting, according to a transcript on Sentieo, a financial-research site.</p><p>\"I hope on my 100th birthday that the Geico people announce to me that they passed State Farm,\" he said. \"But I have to do my share on that, too, by getting to 100.\"</p><h2>2. Huggins' Law</h2><p>Buffett and his business partner, Charlie Munger, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-berkshire-hathaway-dream-business-is-sees-candies-2019-7-1028348838\">acquired See's Candies for $25 million in 1972</a> and immediately put Chuck Huggins in charge.</p><p>In his <a href=\"https://www.berkshirehathaway.com/letters/final1999pdf.pdf\">1999 shareholder letter</a>, Buffett credited Huggins' \"fanatical insistence on both product quality and friendly service\" for See's generating $857 million in pre-tax income since Berkshire took over.</p><p>See's pre-tax profit in millions was about 10% of Huggins' age when he took over aged 46, Buffett said in the letter. That ratio soared to 100% by the time he turned 74, the investor continued.</p><p>\"Having discovered this mathematical relationship &#8212; let's call it Huggins' Law &#8212; Charlie and I now become giddy at the mere thought of Chuck's birthday,\" he joked.</p><h2>3. Buying a furniture store</h2><p>Buffett received a particularly nice birthday gift in 1983 when Mrs B, the 89-year-old owner of Nebraska Furniture Mart, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-berkshire-hathaway-89-mrs-b-fortune-500-ceo-2019-12-1028763487#\">agreed to sell the company to him</a>.</p><p>\"I think back to August 30, 1983 &#8212; my birthday &#8212; when I went to see Mrs B (Rose Blumkin), carrying a one and a quarter-page purchase proposal for NFM that I had drafted,\" he recalled in his <a href=\"https://www.berkshirehathaway.com/letters/2013ltr.pdf\">2013 shareholder letter</a>.</p><p>\"Mrs B accepted my offer without changing a word, and we completed the deal without the involvement of investment bankers or lawyers,\" Buffett continued.</p><p>\"Though the company's financial statements were unaudited, I had no worries,\" he added. \"Mrs B simply told me what was what, and her word was good enough for me.\"</p><h2>4. Business at a party</h2><p>Buffett shared an example of Berkshire's \"carefully crafted and sophisticated acquisition strategy\" in his <a href=\"https://www.berkshirehathaway.com/letters/1996.html\">1996 shareholder letter</a>.</p><p>The investor tried to get out of attending the 40th birthday party of his nephew's wife, Jane Rogers, but agreed to go after learning he would be sitting next to Jane's dad, Roy Dinsdale.</p><p>During the party, Dinsdale revealed he had attended a directors' meeting at Kansas Bankers Surety, an insurance firm that Buffett had long admired. Buffett told Dinsdale to let him know if the company ever came up for purchase.</p><p>Buffett received a letter from Dinsdale a couple of weeks later that contained KBS's financial information. He called Dinsdale the next day to offer $75 million for the company, and the pair soon struck a deal.</p><p>\"I'm now scheming to get invited to Jane's next party,\" Buffett joked.</p><p>If anyone owns a company that meets Berkshire's requirements \"and if I fail to make the next birthday party you attend ... give me a call,\" he added.</p><h2>5. 'I'm really good at this'</h2><p>Buffett famously hires and trusts top-notch managers to run Berkshire's various businesses, freeing him to focus on allocating capital across the company.</p><p>He illustrated the point in his <a href=\"https://www.berkshirehathaway.com/letters/1990.html\">1990 shareholder letter</a>, using a story about his granddaughter Emily's fourth birthday party a few months earlier.</p><p>Beemer the Clown asked Emily to wave a magic wand over a box of wonders.</p><p>\"Loose handkerchiefs went in and, upon a magisterial wave by Emily, emerged knotted,\" Buffett said. \"After four such transformations, each more amazing than its predecessor, Emily was unable to contain herself.\"</p><p>\"Her face aglow, she exulted: 'Gee, I'm really good at this.\"</p><p>\"That sums up my contribution to the performance of Berkshire's business magicians,\" Buffett added, listing several superstars including Mrs B's family and Huggins.</p><p>\"They deserve your applause.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/warren-buffett-90th-birthday-stories-sees-candies-geico-berkshire-hathaway-2020-8'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider/~4/DFRgLNlchqU\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 30 Aug 2020 12:32:00 +0000","feedId":2931,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f492494cd2fec00296a4c9e?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"9d68d061f3aa59f6aad405faebdde06e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn51@2020_5/2020/08/31/06-00-52-351_b47c15ae43e84958.webp","destWidth":2311,"destHeight":1733,"sourceBytes":221432,"destBytes":221432,"author":"tmohamed@businessinsider.com (Theron Mohamed)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f49246ccd2fec00296a4c9b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn89@2020_2/2020/08/31/06-00-54-448_2e4b709c680ac8b7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?i=DFRgLNlchqU:K7Io2c7Kp8E:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn15@2020_6/2020/08/31/06-00-58-961_b1d1d49adb6503aa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn81@2020_2/2020/08/31/06-00-57-877_99a57cc2511f53cd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=bcOpcFrp8Mo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn53@2020_2/2020/08/31/06-00-56-954_403f715e664a4d00.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?i=DFRgLNlchqU:K7Io2c7Kp8E:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn85@2020_2/2020/08/31/06-00-57-260_541c46f33e3b3a72.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=cGdyc7Q-1BI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn70@2020_3/2020/08/31/06-01-02-412_be4dce30169e75ab.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=QXVau8BzmBE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn2@2020_6/2020/08/31/06-01-03-283_c4d57f9dd1ff11a2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn46@2020_1/2020/08/31/06-01-03-681_0165ab2292566722.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=7Q72WNTAKBA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn18@2020_6/2020/08/31/06-00-58-166_b28aa1f69f1eb446.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider/~4/DFRgLNlchqU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn93@2020_5/2020/08/31/06-00-55-908_073076ebbd3c962d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598853650331},{"createdTime":"2020-08-31 14:00:50","updatedTime":"2020-08-31 14:00:50","title":"Airbus just acquired a prop plane to act as a research lab in the sky, collecting data to develop self-flying aircraft – here's how it works","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/airbus-acubed-project-wayfinder-lab-plane-for-autonomous-flight-research-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47bb8ccd2fec00296a4828?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus A350 Autonomous taxi, takeoff, and landing\" height=\"1791\" width=\"2388\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Airbus&#39; self-flying A350-1000 XWB powered by data from Project Wayfinder.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>Airbus' Silicon Valley incubator Acubed is pressing forward with a data collection program that will support future autonomous flight operations.</li><li>Acubed's Project Wayfinder just acquired a Beechcraft Baron 58 and equipped it with onboard cameras and instrumentation to be used as a flying lab for researchers.</li><li>Successful test flights of a self-flying Airbus A350-1000 XWB proved the concept of self-flying planes viable with Project Wayfinder aiming to make it a reality.&#160;</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>Airbus proved that autonomous flight for passenger airliners is possible earlier this year with its <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/airbus-completes-autonomous-taxi-take-off-and-landing-tests-2020-7\">self-flying A350-1000 XWB that performed successful taxi, take-off, and landing tests entirely on its own</a> without pilot input.</p><p>Performing over 500 flights as part of the Autonomous Taxi, Take-off, and Landing project, the aircraft was successfully able to distinguish airport runways and taxiways, skillfully piloting itself through each phase of flight and taking the idea of autopilot to the next level.&#160;</p><p>Each flight was performed at Airbus' headquarters and main production facility in Toulouse, France, where the aircraft performing the tests was also assembled. But the software powering the flights had been driven by data from researchers and engineers 5,000 miles away in the San Francisco Bay Area.</p><p>Airbus' Silicon Valley incubator, Acubed, is home to Project Wayfinder, which aims to create autonomous solutions for the future of flight, whether it be manned and unmanned. Its findings may have implications in the development of new commercial aircraft but could also shape the creation of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/cityairbus-makes-first-public-flight-airbus-flying-taxi-evtol-2020-7\">autonomous air taxi and eVTOL flights</a>.</p><p>Following the success of the autonomous A350 trials, <a href=\"https://acubed.airbus.com/blog/wayfinder/project-wayfinder-flight-test-campaign-we-are-off-the-ground/\">Project Wayfinder just acquired its own flying testbed</a> as part of Airbus' quest to build a robust dataset that will enable autonomous with uses in urban air taxis and commercial aircraft.</p><p>Here's a look inside Project Wayfinder and its newest flying research aircraft.&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tSelf-flying planes were once believed to be the hallmark of a truly futuristic world, a technologically superior era where planes roamed the skies powered by artificial intelligence.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f46c694cd2fec00296a4617?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus A350-1000\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An Airbus A350-1000 XWB aircraft.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tom Buysse/Shutterstock.com</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tBut Airbus has been proving the concept viable using passenger aircraft that are already flying today – such as the A350 – and crafting technology that use machine-learning backed by countless hours of test flight data.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f46c6b3db1ed0002971416d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus A350 Autonomous taxi, takeoff, and landing\" height=\"1773\" width=\"2365\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An Airbus A350-1000 XWB aircraft.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tWith new technology – which integrates with onboard cameras – an Airbus A350-1000 XWB passenger jet was able to recognize taxiways and runways to perform successful take-off, landing, and taxi maneuvers without the pilot touching the controls.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f46c85fcd2fec00296a4628?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus A350 Demonstrates First Fully Automatic Vision Based Take Off\" height=\"664\" width=\"886\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An Airbus A350-1000 XWB test aircraft takes off from Toulouse-Blagnac Airport on its own.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Read More: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/airbus-completes-autonomous-taxi-take-off-and-landing-tests-2020-7\">Airbus' self-flying plane just completed successful taxi, take-off, and landing tests, opening the door for fully autonomous flight</a></em></p>\n\tPilots barely had to do anything besides ensure the plane was making the right calculations and adjustments in each phase of flight.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47bf99cd2fec00296a484e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus A350-1000\" height=\"1388\" width=\"1851\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An Airbus A350-1000 XWB aircraft.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Skycolors/Shutterstock.com</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tEven Airbus' military division is benefiting from autonomous systems, with some being tested on air-to-air refueling planes.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47c033cd2fec00296a4853?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus A310 MRTT air to air refueling\" height=\"1464\" width=\"1952\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An Airbus A310 MRTT performing an air-to-air refueling.\n<p class=\"copyright\">VanderWolf Images / Shutterstock.com</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe tech would recognize fighter jets and other military planes as they approached and conduct an automated refueling process.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f46c749cd2fec00296a4620?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus A330 MRTT\" height=\"1126\" width=\"1502\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An Airbus A310 MRTT performing an automated air-to-air refueling.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Read More </em><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/airbus-a330-achieves-first-aerial-refueling-beats-boeing-2020-4\" data-analytics-position=\"139\" data-analytics-module=\"\">Airbus just beat Boeing to be the first to complete a wholly automated air-to-air refueling operation</a></em></p>\n\tThough, before the tech can be used widespread on planes like the Airbus A350 XWB...\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47d2f1db1ed00029714438?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus A350-1000\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2223\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An Airbus A350-1000 XWB aircraft.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Andreas Zeitler/Shutterstock.com</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tMore data needs to be collected on planes like this one.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4c457f7ffa48002894d134?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Beechcraft Baron 58\" height=\"1058\" width=\"1411\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A Beechcraft Baron 58 similar to the one used by Project Wayfinder.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Richard Thornton/Shutterstock.com</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tProject Wayfinder just acquired this Beechcraft Baron 58 and outfitted it with cameras, sensors, and computers to capture valuable flight data as it flies around the Bay Area.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4810f1db1ed000297145c7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus Acubed Project Wayfinder\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A Beechcraft Baron 58 used by Airbus Acubed&#39;s Project Wayfinder.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus Acubed/Project Wayfinder</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe flying lab collects imagery from each flight which is then auto-labeled and given to machine learning algorithms. That data, in turn, helps the system \"see,\" according to Airbus.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47c18ccd2fec00296a4868?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus Acubed Project Wayfinder\" height=\"1130\" width=\"1507\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Test flight data collected by Project Wayfinder&#39;s Beechcraft Baron 58.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus Acubed/Project Wayfinder</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe onboard cameras work in tandem with navigational charts to collect position data.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47c18ccd2fec00296a4868?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus Acubed Project Wayfinder\" height=\"1130\" width=\"1507\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Test flight data collected by Project Wayfinder&#39;s Beechcraft Baron 58.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus Acubed/Project Wayfinder</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tHere's what the machine sees when the aircraft approaches a runway.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47c16adb1ed000297143a7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus Acubed Project Wayfinder\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Test flight data collected by Project Wayfinder&#39;s Beechcraft Baron 58.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus Acubed/Project Wayfinder</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe green outline indicates that the software recognizes it as a runway and data will be collected to analyze how the plane behaves as it approaches land.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f481129db1ed000297145c9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus Acubed Project Wayfinder\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Test flight data collected by Project Wayfinder&#39;s Beechcraft Baron 58.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus Acubed/Project Wayfinder</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe software needs to be able to detect runways from miles away, which isn't always an easy task.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f481136cd2fec00296a4a5e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus Acubed Project Wayfinder\" height=\"1874\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Test flight data collected by Project Wayfinder&#39;s Beechcraft Baron 58.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus Acubed/Project Wayfinder</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe Baron 58 was chosen, in part, because it's a twin-engine aircraft – like most passenger jets – which leaves the nose area free of obstructions to increase the visibility and field of view for the onboard cameras.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47c162db1ed000297143a5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus Acubed Project Wayfinder\" height=\"1406\" width=\"1875\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A Beechcraft Baron 58 used by Airbus Acubed&#39;s Project Wayfinder.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus Acubed/Project Wayfinder</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tSingle-engine planes typically have a propeller affixed to the nose, which would obstruct the front view of the aircraft.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f481155cd2fec00296a4a62?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus Acubed Project Wayfinder\" height=\"1874\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Test flight data collected by Project Wayfinder&#39;s Beechcraft Baron 58.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus Acubed/Project Wayfinder</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tIt's a far cry from an Airbus A350-1000 XWB but the principles of flight remain the same.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f1b04abf34d0518b371024a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus A350-1000\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2223\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An Airbus A350-1000 XWB aircraft.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Andreas Zeitler/Shutterstock.com</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tOnboard cameras are configured using a black and white checkerboard, called a calibration board.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f48115fcd2fec00296a4a63?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus Accubed Project Wayfinder\" height=\"1406\" width=\"1875\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A Beechcraft Baron 58 used by Airbus Acubed&#39;s Project Wayfinder.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus Accubed/Project Wayfinder</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe successful autonomous flights of the Airbus A350 spurred the ramp-up of data collection at Project Wayfinder.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f48116adb1ed000297145cf?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus Accubed Project Wayfinder\" height=\"1410\" width=\"1875\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A Beechcraft Baron 58 used by Airbus Acubed&#39;s Project Wayfinder.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus Accubed/Project Wayfinder</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe new flying lab took flight on July 28 and is already providing data to Project Wayfinder's machine learning team to process.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f481177cd2fec00296a4a67?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus Accubed Project Wayfinder\" height=\"1410\" width=\"1875\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A Beechcraft Baron 58 used by Airbus Acubed&#39;s Project Wayfinder.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus Accubed/Project Wayfinder</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tTest pilots will continue flying around the Bay Area collecting data while researchers and engineers process the data and fine-tune the hardware and software used for further data collection.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f481185db1ed000297145d0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus Accubed Project Wayfinder\" height=\"1410\" width=\"1875\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A Beechcraft Baron 58 used by Airbus Acubed&#39;s Project Wayfinder.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus Accubed/Project Wayfinder</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tOnce all the data is collected, Project Wayfinder researchers will have a better understanding of just how viable autonomous flight can be on a large scale.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47d9ffdb1ed00029714478?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus Acubed Project Wayfinder\" height=\"1309\" width=\"1746\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A Beechcraft Baron 58 used by Airbus Acubed&#39;s Project Wayfinder.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus Acubed/Project Wayfinder</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tBeyond commercial aircraft, the data provided by the flying lab could also power other autonomous projects like Airbus' eVTOLs program.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47dae9db1ed00029714487?format=jpeg\" alt=\"CityAirbus eVTOL\" height=\"1607\" width=\"2142\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Airbus&#39; CityAirbus eVTOL.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Karl-Josef Hildenbrand/picture alliance/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAirline pilots can also rest easy knowing Project Wayfinder's stated purpose is to increase safety in the cockpit by having autonomous systems reduce pilot workload and not completely replace pilots.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47dfbccd2fec00296a4935?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Airbus A350 cockpit\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2223\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An Airbus A350 XWB cockpit.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dmitry Birin/Shutterstock.com</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 14:00:50","updatedTime":"2020-08-31 14:00:50","title":"Dramatic video shows flower-waving Belarusian women bursting through a police cordon as Minsk protests intensify","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/video-belarusian-women-burst-through-police-cordon-at-minsk-protest-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4b6c9c60bf1f0028079618?format=jpeg\" alt=\"belarus women protest minsk\" height=\"996\" width=\"1328\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Law enforcement officers block a street as women attend a demonstration against police brutality following recent protests to reject the presidential election results in Minsk, Belarus, on August 29, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">BelaPAN via Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>Female protesters broke through a riot police cordon in Minsk, Belarus on Saturday as anti-government demonstrations against President Alexander Lukashenko and his government intensify.</li><li>In a dramatic video, a group of women can be seen pushing back police officers who had their linked arms to create a barrier, while chanting \"this is our city.\"</li><li>The protest marks the latest anti-government demonstrations calling on authoritarian President Lukashenko to step down after a much-disputed election earlier this month.&#160;</li><li>Authorities in Belarus have launched a press crackdown and withdrawn the accreditation of many Belarusian reporters covering the large anti-government protests.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>A phalanx of female protesters broke through a riot police cordon during a protest in Minsk, Belarus, on Saturday, in a dramatic moment captured on video.&#160;</p><p>The incident happened during a so-called \"march of solidarity,\" the latest of a series of anti-government protests that have rocked the country since the disputed presidential election.</p><p>In the video, a group of women push through a line of police officers who had their linked arms to create a barrier. As the police struggle to stick together, the protesters appear to successfully break through the cordon while chanting, \"this is our city.\"</p><p>Later in the video, another powerful moment ensued when female protesters rushed to hug and protect a man who had been approached by a police officer.</p><p><strong>Watch the clip below:&#160;</strong></p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Joyce Karam  (@Joyce_Karam) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1299809568369905675?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">August 29, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p><p>The protest marks the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/belarus-erupts-in-protest-after-opposition-alleges-rigged-election-2020-8?r=US&IR=TIR=T\">latest of anti-government demonstrations that have called on authoritarian President Alexander Lukashenko and his government to step down</a>&#160;after a much-disputed election earlier this month.&#160;</p><p>Lukashenko denies opposition accusations that he rigged the August 9 election to prolong his 26-year rule and claims that the protests &#8212; which have brought hundreds and thousands of people to the streets &#8212; are funded by the West.&#160;</p><p>Many of the protesters were wearing a national dress and were waving flowers and flags, ignoring the calls by police not to disturb public order. Streets along the protest route had been cordoned off and blocked with vans.</p><p>While no mass arrests took place during the march, US state-run Radio Free Europe claimed that the police detained two of its reporters<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/belarus-releasing-detained-protesters-reports-torture-rigged-election-2020-8?r=US&IR=TIR=T\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">.</a></p><p>Authorities in Belarus have withdrawn the accreditation of many journalists reporting on the post-election protest, including two journalists with the BBC's Russian service.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-53924922\">In a statement released on Saturday</a>, the BBC said it condemned \"in the strongest possible terms this stifling of independent journalism.\"</p><p>Read more:</p><ul class=\"read-more-links\"><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/belarus-erupts-in-protest-after-opposition-alleges-rigged-election-2020-8?r=US&IR=TIR=T\" data-read-more-link=\"\" data-e2e-name=\"read-more-link\">Belarus erupts in protest after opposition alleges rigged election</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rnc-used-video-of-barcelona-in-video-about-us-protests-2020-8?r=US&IR=TIR=T\" data-read-more-link=\"\" data-e2e-name=\"read-more-link\">The Republican National Committee used stock footage from a 2019 protest in Spain to show rioting in 'Biden's America'</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/protests-activism-professor-why-george-floyd-movement-is-different-2020-6?r=US&IR=TIR=T\" data-read-more-link=\"\" data-e2e-name=\"read-more-link\">I'm a professor who studies protests and activism. ,{"createdTime":"2020-08-31 14:00:50","updatedTime":"2020-08-31 14:00:50","title":"Job diary: As a professional bridesmaid, I deal with everything from missing grooms to wedding crashers. Here's what a day in my life is really like.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/job-diary-a-day-in-the-life-of-professional-bridesmaid-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47ebcecd2fec00296a499f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"I&#39;m expected to become friends with the other bridesmaids, especially the ones that pose to be a problem throughout the wedding day. Courtesy of Jen Glantz\" height=\"1055\" width=\"1406\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Jen Glantz works as a hired bridesmaid for strangers getting married.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jen Glantz</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li><strong>Jen Glantz is an entrepreneur and founder of the company&#160;<a href=\"http://www.bridesmaidforhire.com/\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"c2e589a2dc7b35842579999ce92e8d3d\">Bridesmaid for Hire</a>, for which she works as a professional bridesmaid in the weddings of complete strangers.</strong></li><li>On the big day, she says her duties involve everything from being the bride's personal assistant, social director, peacekeeper, and unofficial on-call therapist.&#160;</li><li>While no wedding is ever the same, Glantz says there's always family drama, a variety of last-minute problems, and loads of tears.&#160;</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>When I often tell people that I work as a <a href=\"http://www.bridesmaidforhire.com\">bridesmaid for hire</a> they almost immediately think that's just a fancy word for wedding planner.</p><p>But wedding planners are very different: They work on setting up the wedding and coordinating details of the look and feel of the whole celebration.&#160;</p><p>What do I do? It can seem complicated, but my job is more than just wearing the bridesmaid dress, pretending to know the bride from a specific time in her life, dancing on the dance floor, and giving a maid-of-honor speech.</p><p>A lot of what I do requires putting out fights (between the bride and the cast of characters in her life), finding missing things (from bridesmaid dresses to grooms), and running around solving problems (like Diet Coke spilled on the wedding dress before the ceremony, handling a bride with cold feet, or trying to keep the mother of the bride busy so she and the bride don't have another argument). That's the simple version of my job.&#160;</p><p>The heart of my job is being there for the person who hired me, which often means that every wedding looks and feels different from my perspective. Here's what a day in my life looks like.</p><h2><strong>My day often starts before sunrise</strong></h2><p><strong><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47e29acd2fec00296a495c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"I&#39;m the first person to greet the bride on her wedding day. My first job is to pump her up. Courtesy of Jen Glantz\" height=\"902\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>I&#39;m the first person to greet the bride on her wedding day, it&#39;s my job to pump her up.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jen Glantz</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></strong></p><p>I'm the first person at the bride's hotel suite the morning of the wedding and I'm usually there by 6:30 a.m. when she wakes up.&#160;</p><p>I bring her favorite breakfast and a large cup of coffee or tea. I usually also bring flowers to add life and color to the morning. I put on my playlist and help the bride start the day with a quick dance party.&#160;</p><p>We run through the flow of the day and talk through any nerves or problems she anticipates. I organize her dress and accessories before I pack her bag for the wedding and for the wedding night. I also make sure we spend 20 minutes doing some silent meditation and deep breathing before the hair and makeup process begins or the other bridesmaids arrive.&#160;</p><h2><strong>I meet dozens of new people on the morning of the big day</strong></h2><p>Once the other bridesmaids show up, I often meet them for the first time. Of course they question who I am and why I haven't been at any other pre-wedding events. I always have answers ready for each situation and the bride backs me up. I help them steam their dresses and tell them it's my specialty. I also know in advance who will be problematic that day and try to buddy up with them so I can intervene before the drama gets to the bride.</p><p>If there aren't any other bridesmaids, I meet the other people in the bride's life, like parents or family members who are getting ready with her that morning. Usually they pull me aside, talk my ear off with different drama and problems, all without knowing I'm hired to work the wedding.</p><p>Why do they do it? At weddings, everyone involved wants a pair of ears to vent to. I always make mine available so that I have inside access to all the problems taking place, so I can help ease tension among the people there.</p><h2><strong>Tears are inevitable at every wedding</strong></h2><p><strong><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47e32ecd2fec00296a4960?format=jpeg\" alt=\"I bring at least 7 packs of tissues and they all get used throughout the wedding day. Jen Glantz Courtesy of Adam Kossoff\" height=\"902\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>I bring at least seven packs of tissues and they all get used throughout the wedding day.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Adam Kossoff</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></strong></p><p>Usually, right before the ceremony starts, a set of tears begin. Sometimes it's from an overwhelmed or cold-footed bride, other times it's from a bridesmaid who is sabotaging the wedding experience with her emotions and problems. Occasionally it's from a stubborn or opinionated family member. Either way, this is when I pull out my first tissue pack of the day (I carry seven mini tissue packs with me for each wedding &#8212; they always get used).&#160;</p><p>I often spend 15 to 20 minutes inviting the crying person into the hallway with me to talk things out. I'm good at getting them to stop crying and usually that's because I listen, question them, and try to bribe them to calm down (with a mid-morning coffee or pastry).&#160;</p><h2><strong>Problems often pop up last-minute before the ceremony</strong></h2><p>Right before the ceremony, there's always a problem I have to attend to. I make sure I get ready for the wedding as early as possible so I don't have a curling iron in my hand when the morning problem happens. Sometimes it's a stained wedding dress, a missing groom, a hungover bridesmaid, a broken bracelet, a late officiant, or bad weather.</p><p>While I do my best to fix the problem, sometimes I can't, like when there's torrential rain and the wedding is outside without a tent. I do my best to come up with crafty solutions and if that doesn't work, I'm honest with the bride. I'd rather set realistic expectations &#8212; because if not, they count on me to do the impossible, like make the sun come out.&#160;</p><h2><strong>After the ceremony, things slow down and I sneak away for a quick break&#160;</strong></h2><p><strong><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f11a5403ad861163c73c459?format=jpeg\" alt=\"At some weddings, Jen is happy to have it be over so she never has to see the person who hired her again. Courtesy of Jen Glantz\" height=\"901\" width=\"1202\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>When the ceremony is over, I hide in the bathroom for some peace and quiet.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jen Glantz</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></strong></p><p>Once I finish walking down the aisle and the couple has said \"I do,\" things slow down for me. I bustle the bride's dress, bring her and her partner food from cocktail hour, and let them be for a little bit. I go off and hide in a bathroom stall for 30 minutes, take deep breaths, and try to unpack all that happened so far. I often try to sneak in my first meal of the day, since finding time to eat amid nonstop chaos can be tricky, before going back to work.&#160;</p><h2><strong>As cocktail hour gets underway, another problem usually pops up</strong></h2><p>When I exit the bathroom, someone usually grabs me and pulls me toward a problem, such as the couple fighting, a groom who is too drunk already, or a bridesmaid threatening to leave because she feels left out. Most of the time it's that the bride needs help peeing in her wedding dress. I return to the bathroom and spend 20 minutes helping her.</p><h2><strong>I'm</strong><strong> in charge of getting the party started and keeping it going</strong></h2><p><strong><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f11a5fd3f7370464b27efa7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"On rare occasions, Jen says she remains good friends with clients. Courtesy of Jen Glantz\" height=\"1067\" width=\"1422\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>I&#39;m always the first person on the dance floor.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jen Glantz</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></strong></p><p>Once the reception doors open, I'm expected to be the first person on the dance floor. Have you ever danced alone at a wedding while all the guests watched from their tables? That's part of my job. I try to pull people onto the dance floor and make the environment fun. It can be tricky, especially if the crowd isn't interested or the music is bad. But I do what I can to make the night exciting and fun.&#160;</p><h2><strong>As the night wears on, I make a secret exit&#160;</strong></h2><p><strong><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47e410cd2fec00296a4965?format=jpeg\" alt=\"I leave the weddings without saying goodbye. Jen Glantz\" height=\"1200\" width=\"1600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>I leave the weddings without saying goodbye.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jen Glantz</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></strong></p><p>When my time is up (based on how many hours the bride hired me for) I grab my bag and find the exit door. I don't say goodbye because I don't want to draw attention to myself leaving. I try to be as discreet as possible, so I tell people I'm heading to the bathroom, then I call a cab and get back to my hotel or the airport, where I either catch a flight home or continue on to the next wedding of the weekend.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/job-diary-a-day-in-the-life-of-professional-bridesmaid-2020-8'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a "https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn2@2020_6/2020/08/31/06-01-03-283_c4d57f9dd1ff11a2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn46@2020_1/2020/08/31/06-01-03-681_0165ab2292566722.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=7Q72WNTAKBA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn18@2020_6/2020/08/31/06-00-58-166_b28aa1f69f1eb446.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider/~4/ay479TgHCu4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn63@2020_6/2020/08/31/06-00-59-033_691a2ddb03cbcac6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598853650325},{"createdTime":"2020-08-31 14:00:50","updatedTime":"2020-08-31 14:00:50","title":"The Justice Department secretly curtailed the investigation into Trump's links to Russia in 2017: NYT","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/doj-narrowed-investigation-into-trumps-links-to-russia-nyt-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5efa5533f34d05626d67adc4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Trump Putin\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Donald Trump meets with Russian President Vladimir Putin at the G20 leaders summit in Osaka, Japan June 28, 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Kevin Lamarque/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>The Justice Department made an effort to curtail the 2017 investigation into Russian election interference, The New York Times reported Tuesday.</li><li>Former Justice Department and FBI officials told The Times that former Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein secretly narrowed the investigation by ordering special counsel Robert Mueller to conduct the investigation as criminal, not counterintelligence.</li><li>Citing journalist Jeffrey Toobin's book that first reported their conversation, Rosenstein told Mueller: \"I love Ken Starr. But his investigation was a fishing expedition. Don't do that. This is a criminal investigation. Do your job, and then shut it down.\"</li><li>The Times report comes after <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/senate-intel-committee-report-russia-election-interference-biggest-takeaways-2020-8\">a bipartisan report by the Republican-led Senate Intelligence Committee</a>&#160;found that former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort was a \"grave counterintelligence threat\" due to his extensive ties to pro-Russian individuals and entities.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>Former law enforcement officials told The New York Times that the Justice Department made an effort to curtail the 2017 investigation into the Russian election interference and any potential ties to President Donald Trump.</p><p>When appointing Robert Mueller as special counsel of the investigation, former Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein told Mueller to look for \"any links and/or coordination between the Russian government,\" which falls under the purview of a counterintelligence investigation to scope out threats to national security, The Times reported Tuesday.</p><p>But Rosenstein privately told Mueller to conduct it as a criminal investigation, thus building a staff equipped to investigate crimes, not national security threats, former Justice Department and FBI officials told The Times.</p><p>Citing journalist Jeffrey Toobin's book that first reported their conversation, Rosenstein told Mueller: \"I love Ken Starr. But his investigation was a fishing expedition. Don't do that. This is a criminal investigation. Do your job, and then shut it down.\"</p><p>A representative from the Justice Department did not immediately respond to Business Insider's request for comment.</p><p>The Times report comes after <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/senate-intel-committee-report-russia-election-interference-biggest-takeaways-2020-8\">a bipartisan report by the Republican-led Senate Intelligence Committee</a>&#160;found that former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort was a \"grave counterintelligence threat\" due to his extensive ties to pro-Russian individuals and entities.</p><p>\"Taken as a whole, Manafort's high-level access and willingness to share information with individuals closely affiliated with the Russian intelligence services, particularly [Konstantin] Kilimnik and associates of Oleg Deripaska, represented a grave counterintelligence threat,\" the report said.</p><p>Former FBI deputy director Andrew McCabe told The Times that Rosenstein did not run the order to Mueller by him, and if he had known, then the FBI would instead have taken over the investigation.</p><p>\"We opened this case in May 2017 because we had information that indicated a national security threat might exist, specifically a counterintelligence threat involving the president and Russia,\" McCabe told The Times. \"I expected that issue and issues related to it would be fully examined by the special counsel team.\"</p><p>\"If a decision was made not to investigate those issues, I am surprised and disappointed,\" he continued. \"I was not aware of that.\"</p><h2><a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/30/us/politics/trump-russia-justice-department.html\">Read the full story at The New York Times &#187;</a></h2><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original ,{"createdTime":"2020-08-31 14:00:50","updatedTime":"2020-08-31 14:00:50","title":"How Walmart's ad business stacks up to Amazon and why the retailer wants to acquire a piece of TikTok","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/business-insiders-biggest-advertising-and-media-stories-for-august-31-2020-8","description":"<p>Hi! Welcome to the Insider Advertising daily for August 31. I'm Lauren Johnson, a senior advertising reporter at Business Insider. <a href=\"http://newsletter.businessinsider.com/join/4np/insider-advertising\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\">Subscribe here to get this newsletter in your inbox every weekday.</a>&nbsp;Send me feedback or tips at&nbsp;<a href=\"mailto:ljohnson@businessinsider.com\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\">ljohnson@businessinsider.com</a></p>\n<p><strong>Today's news:</strong> How Walmart's ad business stacks up to Amazon, tech salary data, and&nbsp;Netflix's Brazil audience.</p>\n<hr>\n <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ad-insiders-compare-walmarts-advertising-business-with-amazon-2020-8\">\n   <figure> \n    <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5bed75ff38150715d7206bd2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"doug mcmillon walmart\" height=\"682\" width=\"909\" charset=\"\"> \n     <figcaption>\n      Doug McMillon, president and CEO of Walmart \n      <p class=\"copyright\">Paras Griffin/Getty Images for 2017 ESSENCE Festival</p> \n     </figcaption> </img>\n   </figure></a></h3>\n <section>\n  <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ad-insiders-compare-walmarts-advertising-business-with-amazon-2020-8\">Walmart's bid for part of TikTok's ad business shows its ambitions to take on Amazon. E-commerce insiders detail the strengths and weaknesses of its ad strategy.</a></h3>\n </section>\n <section></section>\n <ul>\n  <li>Last week, Walmart confirmed that it worked with Microsoft to make a bid for TikTok's US business to compete with Amazon, particularly in advertising.</li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ad-insiders-compare-walmarts-advertising-business-with-amazon-2020-8\">I looked at how Walmart's advertising business stacks up to Amazon. Advertising experts said that Walmart trails behind Amazon in areas like measurement, its advertising auction, and self-serve technology that lets advertisers of all stripes run campaigns.</a></li>\n  <li>While Walmart has a big opportunity to roll out new technology and use store data to compete with Amazon, ad budgets are significantly smaller than Amazon ad budgets. Curtis Rummel, lead client strategist at e-commerce agency Marketplace Strategy, estimated that clients put 5% to 10% of the budgets that are spent advertising on Amazon on Walmart campaigns.</li>\n </ul>\n <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ad-insiders-compare-walmarts-advertising-business-with-amazon-2020-8\">Read the full story here.</a></h3>\n <hr>\n  <section>\n   <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-marketing-salaries-facebook-google-amazon-twitter-microsoft-uber-airbnb-2020-8\">\n     <figure> \n      <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f36f1a7e89ebf001f044df9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Jack Dorsey\" height=\"2293\" width=\"3057\" charset=\"\"> \n       <figcaption>\n        Twitter CEO Jack Dorsay \n        <p class=\"copyright\">PRAKASH SINGH/AFP via Getty Images</p> \n       </figcaption> </img>\n     </figure></a></h3>\n   <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-marketing-salaries-facebook-google-amazon-twitter-microsoft-uber-airbnb-2020-8\">Tech marketing salaries revealed: What companies like Facebook, Amazon, and Twitter pay employees, from creative directors to managers</a></h3>\n   <ul>\n    <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-marketing-salaries-facebook-google-amazon-twitter-microsoft-uber-airbnb-2020-8\">Patrick Coffee and Tanya Dua looked at how much the biggest tech companies pay for marketing roles, according to &nbsp;the&nbsp;US Office of Foreign Labor Certification's most recent quarterly disclosure data.&nbsp;</a></li>\n    <li>Apple, Amazon, Twitter and other tech companies hire considerably more international talent than many others due to their size and need for people with unique skills.</li>\n    <li>Apple paid a creative director $300,000 while Google paid a director of product marketing $315,000.</li>\n   </ul>\n  </section>\n  <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-marketing-salaries-facebook-google-amazon-twitter-microsoft-uber-airbnb-2020-8\">Read the full story here.</a></h3>\n  <hr>\n   <section>\n    <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/analysts-estimate-brazil-more-netflix-subscribers-than-pay-tv-2020-8\">\n      <figure> \n       <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4918c4cd2fec00296a4c4f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"3% Brazil\" height=\"1687\" width=\"2250\" charset=\"\"> \n        <figcaption>\n         A still from season four of \"3%\" on Netflix. \n         <p class=\"copyright\">Netflix</p> \n        </figcaption> </img>\n      </figure></a></h3>\n    <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/analysts-estimate-brazil-more-netflix-subscribers-than-pay-tv-2020-8\">Brazil now has more Netflix subscribers than pay-TV households, according to Bernstein analysts. Here are 3 takeaways from their report about the key streaming market.</a></h3>\n    <ul>\n     <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/analysts-estimate-brazil-more-netflix-subscribers-than-pay-tv-2020-8\">A new report from Bernstein analysts finds that there are more Netflix subscribers than pay-TV subscribers in Brazil.</a></li>\n     <li>Ashley Rodriguez reports that the Wall Street firm estimates that Netflix has 17 million paying subscribers in Brazil (compared to more than 60 million paying subscribers in the US). Netflix was the first big streaming company to launch a subscription service in Brazil. And rivals HBO Max and Disney Plus could enter the country soon.</li>\n     <li>On average, English-language programming filled six of Netflix Brazil's top 1o titles each week from March to August, suggesting that there may be room in Netflix's library for more local-language content.</li>\n    </ul>\n   </section>\n   <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/analysts-estimate-brazil-more-netflix-subscribers-than-pay-tv-2020-8\">Read the full story here.</a></h3>\n   <hr>\n    <h3><strong>More stories we're reading:</strong></h3>\n    <section>\n     <section>\n      <section>\n       <ul>\n        <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/att-mulling-possible-sale-of-directv-deal-report-2020-8\">AT&amp;T is reportedly mulling a possible sale of DirecTV</a>&nbsp;(Business Insider)</li>\n        <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-us-ban-hiring-freeze-shutdown-contingency-plan-donald-trump-2020-8\">TikTok has enacted a hiring freeze and drawn up a shutdown contingency plan ahead of threat of US ban</a>&nbsp;(Business Insider)</li>\n        <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biggest-private-equity-tech-investors-kkr-carlyle-enterprise-software-deals-2020-8\">Big private-equity firms are piling into tech deals. Top execs at Carlyle, KKR, and Warburg Pincus laid out how they're angling for an edge.</a>&nbsp;(Business Insider)</li>\n        <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-much-money-micro-influencers-charge-instagram-brand-sponsorships-2020-8\">4 Instagram 'micro' influencers explain how much money they charge brands for sponsorships</a>&nbsp;(Business Insider)</li>\n        <li><a href=\"https://mynewsla.com/business/2020/08/27/black-woman-alleges-race-played-role-in-her-firing-from-ad-agency/\">Black woman alleges race played role In her firing from ad agency</a>&nbsp;(MyNewsLA)</li>\n        <li><a href=\"https://www.adweek.com/programmatic/programmatic-returning-prepandemic-normal-levels/\">Programmatic is returning to its prepandemic 'normal' levels</a>&nbsp;(Adweek)</li>\n       </ul>\n      </section>\n     </section>\n    </section>\n    <section></section>\n    <p>Thanks for reading and see you tomorrow! 14:00:50","updatedTime":"2020-08-31 14:00:50","title":"The S&P 500 could rise 11% and 'flirt with 3,900' by end of 2020 if Trump's game-changing vaccine plan works before the election","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-outlook-sp-500-rise-trump-vaccine-plan-works-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4525f789aff80028ab7bc6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"trump visits north carolina fujifilm vaccine Novavax\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>U.S. President Donald Trump gestures during a tour of the Fujifilm Diosynth Biotechnologies&#39; Innovation Center, a pharmaceutical manufacturing plant where components for a potential coronavirus disease (COVID-19) vaccine candidate Novavax are being developed, in Morrrisville, North Carolina, U.S., July 27, 2020\n<p class=\"copyright\">Carlos Barria/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/s&p_500_500\">S&#38;P 500 </a>can explode a further 11% and touch 3,900 before year end if Trump's revolutionary vaccine plan gets recognized, a CEO of an online trading platform said.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong>Anthony Denier, CEO of Webull told Business Insider: \"I would predict the S&#38;P to flirt with 3,900.\"</strong></li><li><strong>Trump announced this week the White House is mulling an emergency use authorization for UK-based AstraZeneca's experimental vaccine before the November election.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong>The S&#38;P 500 hit multiple record highs this week following the news, and closed above 3,500 on Friday.</strong></li><li><strong>But veteran strategist Ed Yardeni told Business Insider that while he is still bullish on the index, most vaccine news has already been priced in. </strong></li><li><strong>\"Its already gone to the moon on a rocket ship,\" he said.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</strong></li></ul><hr ><p>The <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/s&p_500_500\">S&#38;P 500</a> could balloon 11% from its current explosive level before the end of the 2020 if US President Trump's revolutionary vaccine plan gets realized before the November election, according to the CEO of a trading platform.&#160;</p><p>Anthony Denier, CEO of trading platform <a href=\"https://www.webull.com/\">Webul</a><a href=\"https://www.webull.com/activity/stocks-offer?source=google-search-pc-pp-gw&gclid=EAIaIQobChMI1MPFsqK56wIVFY3ICh2KQgjkEAAYASAAEgLe7_D_BwE_BwE\">l</a>, told Business Insider: \"Social sentiment aside, if Trump succeeds in getting a treatment to the US that results in 35% less deaths due to COVID-19, and we continue to see infection rates decline, then this would give him a strong tailwind into the election for another four year term.\"</p><p>\"I would predict the S&#38;P to flirt with 3,900,\" he added. Climbing to 3,900 would represent an increase of some 11% from Friday's closing price.</p><p>The S&#38;P 500 has bounced back from hell after touching coronavirus lows in March. It hit a new record of 3,508 points on Friday, gaining all week after it emerged Tuesday that Trump is mulling an emergency use authorization for an early stage coronavirus vaccine being developed by AstraZeneca in the UK.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-picks-to-buy-hedge-mutual-funds-market-favorites-goldman-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">GOLDMAN SACHS: Buy these 9 stocks that are poised to continue crushing the market as the 'shared favorites' of Wall Street's biggest investors</a></em></p><p>Such an action would bypass regulatory standards and potentially introduce a vaccine to the US market before November's presidential election.</p><p>The S&#38;P 500 index has bounced 53% since touching coronavirus lows in March.&#160;</p><p>A raft of factors has contributed to the index's spectacular recovery. Central banks across the world rolled out stimulus packages to help companies survive the pandemic. This has left interest rates and yields at rock bottom, making the stock market an attractive place to make money.&#160;</p><p>Investors have been very sensitive to all types of news, particularly on anything related to the likelihood of a vaccine being developed in the near future.&#160;</p><p>Separately, the Food and Drug Administration issued <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fda-approves-unproven-plasma-treatment-for-covid-19-2020-8?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">emergency authorization</a>&#160;for using convalescent plasma to treat COVID-19.</p><p>While Denier thinks the S&#38;P 500 could touch 3,900 should Trump successfully bring a vaccine to the US pre-election, veteran strategist Ed Yardeni is less convinced the vaccine news can move markets higher, adding that any news on such front is likely already priced into the S&#38;P 500 index.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-david-rosenberg-dot-com-tech-bubble-distortions-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">35-year market vet David Rosenberg warns the stock market's rally features distortions that were glaring during the tech bubble &#8212; and lays out his plausible scenario for a crash</a></em></p><p>Yardeni, president of Yardeni Research told Business Insider: \"I said before we're going to go to 3,500 before the end of the year and then 3,800 next year. But the market keeps getting to the levels well ahead of schedule.\"&#160;</p><p>\"If this vaccine use just came out of the blue and we hadn't had a lot of other encouraging news on the vaccines for the past several months, the market would be going to the moon on a rocket ship,\" Yardeni said. \"But it's already gone to the moon on a rocket ship.\"</p><p>Yardeni said Trump's \"very vague plan\" was simply an effort to ramp up as much positive news in the week of the Republican convention.&#160;</p><p>As long as the perception is that the global economy is recovering, then markets can reach 3,800 earlier than next year, he said.&#160;</p><p>But the index shooting up to these levels on vaccine news alone is unlikely, he concluded.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-david-morgan-report-expert-warns-likely-meltdown-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">'Basically one mass manipulation': A market expert unloads on the central bank-driven 'failure' of the modern financial system &#8212; and says another stock meltdown is likely coming</a></em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original 16:05:00 +0000","feedId":2931,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f45271142f43f001ddfed7f?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"76cdb5cd6fc3e7c21e309ae11153eb2e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn15@2020_6/2020/08/31/06-00-52-345_a50f7abb4f5ec99b.webp","destWidth":2848,"destHeight":2136,"sourceBytes":256340,"destBytes":256340,"author":"insider@insider.com (Saloni Sardana)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f4525f789aff80028ab7bc6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn6@2020_6/2020/08/31/06-01-00-328_407665f57a31a2f8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?i=xRRf6Vy2R8Y:7J6dJgccmmg:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn9@2020_1/2020/08/31/06-01-02-670_f6c38923a246844b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn81@2020_2/2020/08/31/06-00-57-877_99a57cc2511f53cd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=bcOpcFrp8Mo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn53@2020_2/2020/08/31/06-00-56-954_403f715e664a4d00.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?i=xRRf6Vy2R8Y:7J6dJgccmmg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn69@2020_2/2020/08/31/06-00-53-641_0013325e155ea926.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=cGdyc7Q-1BI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn70@2020_3/2020/08/31/06-01-02-412_be4dce30169e75ab.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=QXVau8BzmBE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn2@2020_6/2020/08/31/06-01-03-283_c4d57f9dd1ff11a2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn46@2020_1/2020/08/31/06-01-03-681_0165ab2292566722.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider?d=7Q72WNTAKBA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn18@2020_6/2020/08/31/06-00-58-166_b28aa1f69f1eb446.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/typepad/alleyinsider/silicon_alley_insider/~4/xRRf6Vy2R8Y":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn37@2020_5/2020/08/31/06-01-03-611_876015241d228ec1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598853650325},{"createdTime":"2020-08-31 14:00:50","updatedTime":"2020-08-31 14:00:50","title":"The fight over masks is really a debate over how Americans view our fundamental freedoms","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/fight-anti-masks-coronavirus-pandemic-freedom-us-politics-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f46cf46cd2fec00296a4685?format=jpeg\" alt=\"anti mask man cutout protest\" height=\"1500\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A &#39;Hazardous Liberty! Defend the Constitution!&#39; rally to protest the stay-at-home order in Olympia, Washington.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Karen Ducey / Stringer</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>During this pandemic, the way we view our safety versus the way we view the safety of others illustrates a divide in how Americans view basic liberties.</li><li>The debate over wearing masks is a perfect example of this.</li><li>There are four views of liberty according to author David Hackett Fischer, and they each illuminate the way Americans are behaving during the pandemic.</li><li>George Pearkes is the Global Macro Strategist for&#160;<a href=\"https://www.bespokepremium.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.bespokepremium.com&source=gmail&ust=1560533162728000&usg=AFQjCNHnk_YwxDUEQgtqSaaSJXi2S4yC9AaSJXi2S4yC9A\">Bespoke Investment Group</a>.</li><li>This is an opinion column. The thoughts expressed are those of the author.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>How we treat other people in society reveals our fundamental understanding of liberty. Different understandings of the concept of liberty have very different impacts on individuals and society as a whole, and the arrival of COVID is helping to highlight the tradeoffs of the freedoms we preserve for ourselves and each other.&#160;</p><p>In the midst of a global pandemic, the liberties we take with others' safety and the liberties we hold for ourselves reveal fundamental, competing differences in how Americans conceive of our freedoms.</p><p>But the coronavirus offers a chance for us to reassess our assumptions about the costs to others that taking liberties impose, and illustrate the need for a more egalitarian approach to making our way in the world.</p><h2>Four views of liberty</h2><p>In his massive book on the migratory origins of America's voluntary society, <em>Albion's Seed</em>, David Hackett Fischer identifies four different conceptions of \"liberty\" that all found their way into our national political culture: ordered, hierarchical, natural, and reciprocal.</p><p>These liberties are different ways of viewing the concept of freedom, and they have all played roles in American culture. The conflicts in our society highlighted by COVID generally and the push to wear a mask specifically neatly highlight these various conceptions of freedom.</p><p>Efforts to require masks are a straightforward expression of <em>ordered</em> liberty. The concept of ordered liberty argues that without structure and a set of rules which are enforced for the common good, society would devolve into chaos. Mask orders are quite literally saving society from itself, so that we can be more free than we would if COVID spread even further and faster.</p><p><em>Hierarchical</em> liberty takes a different view: that hierarchy is the source of liberty. In this understanding, people of a lower rank do not have the same liberties or rights as those with higher rank, and that system of inequality actually improves society. To a believer in hierarchical liberty, hierarchy brings harmony and therefore freedom.</p><p>You won't find much respect for hierarchical liberty among those who follow a more <em>natural</em> liberty, which boils down to refusing any authority at all. Mask orders from local government and local business are seen as equally unacceptable to a natural libertarian, but they're also not going to be bothered by someone else deciding to mask...after all, that's their business.</p><p>Finally, we come to <em>reciprocal</em> liberty, which is best thought of as a generic application of <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Rule\">The Golden Rule</a>. Under principles of reciprocal liberty, any threat to one person's freedom or safety is a threat to the freedom or safety of all people, because that same threat may eventually be turned on whoever is avoiding it today. This approach would dictate mask-wearing not out of paternalistic concern for the wearer, but out of the wearer's concern that they may endanger the people they interact with.</p><p>These principles of liberty may be understood through a meal at a restaurant.</p><p>A diner focused on ordered liberty would assiduously follow the rules for patrons laid out by the restaurant itself, and by applicable government regulation. If not required to by the rules established, the diner wouldn't wear a mask. The fact that staff did wear masks wouldn't be strange to them...after all, the rules don't say they can serve without a mask, unlike the diner.</p><p>If that same diner had a hierarchical view of liberty, they might decide it was right and proper for the diner to be protected by mask-wearing staff's face coverings, but pay no mind to the risks their unmasked exhales create for staff. After all, there is an order established, and their liberty is greater being from a higher class or socioeconomic standing.</p><p>The natural libertarian may reject wearing a mask in the restaurant, complain about how spaced out seats were, or go the other way entirely and assiduously dine in an N95 out of fear of the virus. Either way, others wouldn't factor much in their thinking, regardless of position.</p><p>Finally, a reciprocal conception of liberty would dictate that any time a server approached the table, diners would pause, don masks, and keep them on until distance was re-established. After all, the server is at risk if the diners are not wearing masks themselves.</p><p>My wife and I decided that our first dinner out in a post-COVID world would be dictated by those reciprocal principles. It made the meal quite nerve-wracking by the standards of fine dining, both in terms of explaining our thinking to staff who had not encountered that sort of behavior before, and because we had to constantly look out for servers approaching the table. But we also felt more comfortable knowing that we were doing our best to treat servers as we expected to be treated ourselves.</p><h2>American liberties before the virus</h2><p>Our stratified and increasingly unequal society has been cast in even sharper relief by COVID. By-and-large, American society has steered further towards its hierarchical influences over the last several decades, with some influences of ordered and natural liberty sprinkled in.</p><p>Our economic model is reliant on services consumption, and the conventional wisdom for successful service is \"the customer is always right\". This dynamic appeals to both hierarchical and natural concepts of liberty: customers are on a pedestal above the services workers who cater to them, and face little restriction in their desires from any authority.</p><p>In a system of ordered libertarian thinking, disrupting a business because an order is incorrect makes no sense; a loud argument that bothers others is just as problematic as an incorrect order. Similarly, venting frustration and petty tyranny upon service workers makes no sense to a reciprocal libertarian, because receiving that sort of treatment is such a difficult experience.</p><p>Another example of hierarchical liberty current reckoning with police violence. But unlike consumer culture, police brutality appeals to ordered liberty; a conception of freedom requiring order sits at the core of any argument that atrocious force in response to disruption is justified.&#160;</p><h2>A path forward</h2><p>Just as the virus may offer us the opportunity to make choices that are more reciprocal, society as a whole would be well-served by a reciprocal approach to problem solving.&#160;</p><p>At the individual level, it requires a simple application of human empathy. In any situation of conflict or dispute, simply asking oneself \"how would I feel being treated the way I am treating someone else?\" can go a long way.</p><p>In public policy, renewed focus on solutions grounded in consent, agency, and discussion are more reciprocal than institutions which enforce order, create hierarchy, or retreat from intervention of any kind. Reciprocal libertarians always take up the pen and the chat over the gun or the court, and encouraging that sort of approach would do much to improve conditions for all Americans.</p><div
